posts.title: Vietnam bans unskippable ads
posts.author: hoherd
posts.title_cn: 越南禁止不可跳过的广告
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕越南禁止不可跳过广告的新闻展开。社区普遍对移动应用中的侵入式广告表示反感，许多用户分享了个人经历，例如因广告过多而卸载游戏，或不得不让孩子在飞行模式下玩游戏以避免广告干扰。有人认为广告策略日益令人厌烦，特别是进度条欺骗或长时间不可跳过的插页广告。

讨论中提到广告商业模式的社会影响，有观点指出广告驱动可能导致服务商刻意制造用户成瘾，损害社会价值。也有用户对监管效果表示怀疑，认为此举可能只是促使广告商增加可跳过广告的数量，而非真正改善体验。在技术层面，部分用户强调通过工具屏蔽广告是维护设备自主权的必要手段。

共识在于普遍厌恶当前移动广告的过度侵扰，但分歧体现在解决方案上：部分人支持政府监管，另一部分则更倾向于个人技术手段或行业自律。此外，有用户注意到新闻标题中“Vietnam”的拼写错误，引发了关于英文拼写稳定性的次要讨论。

comments.author: jason_s
comments.content: I just uninstalled a game from my mobile phone this morning that had heavy ad usage. It was interesting to note the different ad display strategies. From least to most annoying:- display a static ad, have the "x" to close appear soon (3-10 seconds)- display an animated ad, have the "x" to close appear soon (3-10 seconds)- display a static ad, have the "x" to close appear after 20-30 seconds- display an animated ad, have the "x" to close appear after 20-30 seconds- display several ads in succession, each short, but it automatically proceeds to the next; the net time after which the "x" to close appears after 20-30 seconds- display several ads in succession, each lasts for 3-10 seconds but you have to click on an "x" to close each one before the next one appearsI live in the USA. The well-established consumer product brands (Clorox, McDonalds, etc.) almost all had short ads that were done in 3-5 seconds. The longest ads were for obscure games or websites, or for Temu, and they appeared over and over again, making me hate them with a flaming passion. The several-ads-in-succession were usually British newspaper websites (WHY???? I don't live there) or celebrity-interest websites (I have no interest in these).It seems like the monkey's-paw curse for this kind of legislation is to show several ads in a row, each allowing you to skip them after 5 seconds.
comments.content_cn:
今天早上我刚卸载了手机上一款广告繁多的游戏。有趣的是我注意到了不同的广告展示策略，按烦人程度从低到高排列：
- 展示静态广告，很快（3-10秒）出现关闭按钮"x"
- 展示动态广告，很快（3-10秒）出现关闭按钮"x"
- 展示静态广告，20-30秒后才出现关闭按钮"x"
- 展示动态广告，20-30秒后才出现关闭按钮"x"
- 连续播放多个短广告，自动跳转下一个，累计20-30秒后才出现关闭按钮"x"
- 连续播放多个广告，每个持续3-10秒，但必须逐个点击"x"才能关闭

我住在美国。知名消费品品牌（高乐氏、麦当劳等）的广告几乎都是3-5秒的短广告。最长的广告来自冷门游戏或网站，或是Temu，它们反复出现，让我深恶痛绝。连续播放的广告通常是英国新闻网站（为什么？？我又不住那里）或明星八卦网站（我对此毫无兴趣）。

这类法规似乎产生了适得其反的效果——现在变成连续播放多个广告，每个都允许5秒后跳过。

comments.author: DrewADesign
comments.content: My favorite most annoying ad tactic is the trick slowing down progress bar. It starts off fast making it seem like it’s going to be, say, a ten-second ad so you decide to suffer through it… but progressively slows so you notice at like the 20 second mark you’re only 2/3 of the way through the progress bar, so probably less than halfway done. Murderous rage.
comments.content_cn: 我最讨厌的广告伎俩就是那种故意放慢进度条的把戏。一开始它走得飞快，让你以为可能只是个十秒广告，于是你决定忍一忍……结果它越走越慢，等到二十秒时你才发现进度条才走了三分之二，实际进度可能连一半都不到。简直让人火冒三丈。

comments.author: kfarr
comments.content: As much as this may have unintended consequences, I can appreciate the motivation. I can't let my kids play iPhone games unless I turn the device into Airplane mode. Almost all these pay to play mobile games have 60 second interstitials after each level that can't be skipped. It's insane. I've taught my kids how to force kill the game and reload to get out. Definitely depressing compared to the PC shareware days I grew up with.
comments.content_cn: 尽管这可能带来意想不到的后果，但我能理解其初衷。除非我把设备调成飞行模式，否则我根本不敢让孩子玩iPhone游戏。几乎所有这类付费手游在每关结束后都有无法跳过的60秒广告，这简直太疯狂了。我已经教会孩子们如何强制关闭游戏再重新加载来跳过广告。相比我成长过程中接触的PC共享软件时代，这确实令人沮丧。

comments.author: _jab
comments.content: I've often wondered whether the world would be better without ads. The incentive to create services (especially in social media) that strive to addict their users feels toxic to society. Often, it feels uncertain whether these services are providing actual value, and I suspect that whether a user would pay for a service in lieu of watching ads is incidentally a good barometer for whether real value is present.Don't get me wrong, I'm well aware this is impractical. But it's fun to think about sometimes.
comments.content_cn: 我常常思考，如果没有广告，世界是否会变得更好。那些致力于让用户上瘾的服务（尤其是社交媒体）的动机，对社会来说似乎是有害的。这些服务是否提供了真正的价值，常常令人感到不确定。我怀疑，用户是否愿意付费以替代观看广告，恰好是衡量其是否具有真实价值的一个很好的指标。别误会，我很清楚这并不现实。但有时想想也挺有趣的。

comments.author: stephen_g
comments.content: The main app I use with unskippable ads (usually for crappy games, ugh) is FlightRadar24 - since it remembers where you were on the map, I will always just swipe up and kill the app, and it's usually not to hard to find what I was looking at again after re-opening. Of course that wouldn't work with something with more state but I'm glad I can do that.
comments.content_cn: 我主要使用带有无法跳过广告的应用（通常是那些糟糕的游戏，唉）是FlightRadar24——因为它会记住你在地图上的位置，我总是直接上滑关闭应用，重新打开后通常不难找回之前查看的内容。当然，这对状态更复杂的应用可能不适用，但我很高兴能这样操作。

comments.author: catapart
comments.content: Not a great regulatory move, in my opinion. But I really wish ad companies would implement this rule across the board. If you can't sell me on your ad in 5 seconds, it's unlikely you can sell me on your product in 15 or 30 seconds. And if your product is of any interest to me whatsoever, I'm happy to continue watching the ad. I sit through movie trailers and tech ads all the time, even with an option to skip. But I have no use for seeing the entire Dawn dish soap's aw-shucks, faux-folksy ad play out. In five seconds, you can remind me that dawn exists, fulfilling the main purpose of the ad, and I can get on with the content I'm actually interested in.
comments.content_cn: 在我看来这不是一个明智的监管举措。但我真心希望广告公司能全面推行这条规则。如果你无法在5秒内用广告吸引我，那15或30秒的广告也很难让我对你的产品产生兴趣。如果产品本身能引起我的关注，我很乐意继续观看广告。我经常完整观看电影预告片和科技广告，即使有跳过选项。但像Dawn洗洁精那种故作朴实、假装亲切的广告，我完全没有耐心看完。五秒钟足够提醒我Dawn这个品牌的存在，这已实现广告的主要目的，我就能继续观看真正感兴趣的内容了。

comments.author: xp84

In return, you pay seven measly bucks a month (though I have it included as part of a package since we use iCloud and Apple Music and Apple TV+ anyway).The games in AA are either made for Apple Arcade (some great indie type games) or, very commonly, they are basically 'de-fanged' ones from the regular App Store, with all the IAPs and ads ripped out. Where there is an in-game currency that normally is scarce without paying, they'll either just give you a bunch of it to start with, or you will earn it naturally while playing.I agree with you that the number of ads and purchase-pushing mechanics in all regular App Store/Play Store games is insane. It's all because a few whales who do buy these purchases are what pays for the whole thing.

PiHole is fine, I guess. I'm not a huge fan of it personally because:  - It's local network only, and while I can VPN home, I don't always want to
  - It has a high maintenance overhead, at least for me. It would block too much, then my wife would complain, and I'd have to spend time figuring out the magic rule that was breaking.

comments.author: btown
comments.content: As a full mea culpa, I once implemented this years ago for an open-source project (non-ad-related) that could have an unpredictable number of steps with unpredictable timing. We went with an algorithm that would add a % of the remaining progress on each status tick, so, while it would inevitably decelerate, at least users would know that the processing wasn't just frozen.It was a compromise that let us focus our limited attention on the things our project could uniquely do, without needing to refactor or do fast-and-slow-passes to provide subtask-count estimates to the UI. I'd make those same choices again, in that context. But in an ad context, it's inexcusable.
comments.content_cn: 作为一次彻底的自我检讨，多年前我曾在一个开源项目（非广告相关）中实现过类似方案，该项目可能包含步骤数量和时间都不确定的情况。我们采用了一种算法，在每次状态更新时增加剩余进度的百分比，这样虽然进度不可避免地会减速，但至少用户能知道处理过程没有卡住。这是一种折中方案，让我们能将有限的精力集中在项目独有的功能上，无需重构或进行快慢双通道处理来为界面提供子任务数量估算。在当时的背景下，我仍会做出同样的选择。但在广告场景下，这种做法是不可原谅的。

comments.author: grayhatter
comments.content: > But I really wish ad companies would implement this rule across the board. If you can't sell me on your ad in 5 seconds, it's unlikely you can sell me on your product in 15 or 30 seconds.When talking about how ads "don't work on you"; it's very important to remember that just like every single other human you're not immune to propaganda.
comments.content_cn: 但我真心希望广告公司能全面推行这条规则：如果五秒内你的广告无法打动我，那么十五或三十秒的广告更不可能让我对你的产品产生兴趣。当谈论广告"对你无效"时，必须记住——就像所有普通人一样，你同样无法对宣传攻势完全免疫。

comments.author: austin-cheney
comments.content: > Not a great regulatory move, in my opinion.Why?
comments.content_cn: 在我看来，这不是一个明智的监管举措。原因何在？

comments.author: vladms
comments.content: While I agree that the world would be better without ads in their current form, we should think why are ads required and what are the benefits.The main issue is how you discover a new product. The main benefit to society is/could be faster progress. The main downside to society could be unhappy people that consume crap.I think smart people should think about alternative solutions, not just think "ads are the problem".I personally have the exactly same issues as above when I look for example for open source libraries/programs for a task. There are popular ones, there are obscure ones, they are stable ones, etc. The search space is so big and complex that it is never easy.My personal preference would be a network recommendation system. I would like to know what people I know (and in my extended network) are using and like - being it restaurants, clothes or open source software. I have 90% of friends (or friends of friends) satisfied with something - maybe I should try. Of course it is not a perfect system, but seems much better than what we currently have...
comments.content_cn:
虽然我同意没有当前形式的广告世界会更美好，但我们应当思考广告为何存在及其益处。核心问题在于如何发现新产品。对社会的主要益处可能在于推动更快的进步。而主要弊端则可能是人们消费劣质产品导致不满。我认为聪明人应该思考替代方案，而非简单认定“广告即问题根源”。

以我寻找开源库/程序为例，就面临完全相同的困境：有热门选项、冷门选择、稳定版本等等。搜索空间庞大复杂，从来都不轻松。我个人更倾向于网络推荐系统——希望了解我认识的人（以及延伸社交圈）正在使用且喜欢什么，无论是餐厅、服装还是开源软件。如果90%的朋友（或朋友的朋友）对某事物满意，或许我就该尝试。当然这并非完美体系，但似乎远胜当前现状。

comments.author: jonny_eh
comments.content: > I think it would have been a better world without ads. There would be more competition which would improve products and thus outcome for customers.How would people learn about various choices?
comments.content_cn: 我认为没有广告的世界会更美好。竞争会更加激烈，从而提升产品质量，最终让顾客受益。但人们该如何了解各种选择呢？

comments.author: oneeyedpigeon
comments.content: Maybe. Or maybe we could fund those services from all the money we'd save without advertising.
comments.content_cn: 或许吧。或者我们可以用省下的广告费来资助这些服务。

comments.author: somenameforme
comments.content: Most internet services are very low cost to offer for any company that has some infrastructure setup already. So for instance 'back in the day', before Google hoovered up everybody's email, what would typically happen is you would get an email address with your ISP.
comments.content_cn: 对于任何已具备基础设施的公司而言，提供大多数互联网服务的成本都非常低。例如，在谷歌席卷所有人邮箱的"旧日时光"里，通常的情况是你会从网络服务提供商那里获得一个电子邮箱地址。

comments.author: abuob
comments.content: Probably not too popular of an opinion on HN but email in my opinion would be a great example of a service that could be run by the government. Just like postal service (at least in some parts of the world)
comments.content_cn: 在Hacker News上这可能不算主流观点，但我认为电子邮件服务完全可以由政府来运营，就像邮政服务一样（至少在世界某些地区是如此）。

comments.author: Aachen
comments.content: > ads make available a huge amount of media and services to people who would otherwise be unable to afford it.They don't. Follow the money: why do ads power free services? The advertiser needs to expect to make more money in the scenario where they run the ad as compared to where they don't. The viewer must be spending more money in response to having seen itIf the viewer doesn't have the money to pay the first party fair and straight (say, a video website), they also don't have money to splurge on that fancy vacuum cleaner in addition to the website and advertisement broker getting paid, no matter how many ads you throw at themAds are useful for honest products, like if I were to start a company and believe that I've made a vacuum cleaner that's genuinely better (more or better cleaning at a lower or equal cost) but nobody knows about it yet. However, I don't see the point in money redirection schemes where affluent people inefficiently pay for public services (if they're indistinguishable and the company shows ads to both, thereby funding the poor people's usage). Let's do that through taxes please
comments.content_cn: 广告让那些原本负担不起的人能够接触到海量媒体和服务。但事实并非如此。追本溯源：为何广告能支撑免费服务？广告主投放广告的预期收益必须高于不投放的情况。观看者看到广告后必须增加消费支出。如果观看者连直接向第一方（比如视频网站）支付合理费用都负担不起，那么无论向他们投放多少广告，他们也不可能在支付网站和广告中介费用之余，还有闲钱挥霍购买那些花哨的吸尘器。广告对诚信产品是有用的，比如我创办一家公司，相信自己研发的吸尘器确实更优质（以相同或更低成本实现更好清洁效果），但尚未打开知名度时。然而，我不理解那种让富裕人群低效承担公共服务费用的资金转移方案（如果贫富用户无差别，公司向所有人展示广告，实则用富人贡献的广告收入补贴穷人的使用成本）。这类事情请通过税收体系来实现吧。

comments.author: stemlord
comments.content: Then we'd be living in a world that didn't require you to have an email in order to do anything like have a job or a social life, which is probably a good thing
comments.content_cn: 那样我们就能生活在一个无需电子邮件也能工作或社交的世界，这或许是件好事。

comments.author: tcfhgj
comments.content: Other types of micro transactions and payments are possible
comments.content_cn: 其他类型的微交易和支付也是可行的。

comments.author: crims0n
comments.content: I too struggle with this. It's not like people can't publish things on the web without ads. If the author/artist wanted it to be free, the ads wouldn't be there. So people who use ad blockers are either making a moral choice to consume a paid service for free, or are ignorant of how the internet economy works.There is an argument to be made that advertisements are so detrimental to the user experience and mental health of the recipient that they are morally justified in blocking them. However, that is debatable when you consider the alternative, which is that the medium you are consuming may not exist at all if not for the advertisements published along with it.
comments.content_cn: 我也深有同感。人们并非不能在网络上发布无广告的内容。如果作者或艺术家希望作品免费，就不会有广告存在。因此，使用广告拦截器的人要么是出于道德选择，免费享受本应付费的服务，要么就是对互联网经济的运作方式一无所知。有一种观点认为，广告对用户体验和接收者的心理健康极为有害，因此屏蔽广告在道德上是合理的。然而，当你考虑到另一种可能——如果没有伴随的广告，你所消费的媒介可能根本不会存在时，这一点就值得商榷了。

comments.author: OkayPhysicist
comments.content: Most things worth doing on the internet are either A) paid for B) garner enough good will that they can be supported via some polite pan-handling or C) cheap enough to operate that it's a perfectly acceptable hobby expense for 1 person in your community.Streaming services and E-commerce are the classic examples for A. Wikipedia is the quintessential example for B. C includes pretty much all the social outlets: Web forums, a Matrix server, private game servers (public game servers fall under A), blogs, etc.
comments.content_cn: 互联网上大多数值得做的事情通常分为三类：A) 付费服务；B) 积累足够善意后可通过礼貌募捐维持；C) 运营成本低廉，足以成为社区中某个人可承受的爱好支出。流媒体服务和电子商务是A类的典型代表，维基百科是B类的典范，而C类则涵盖了几乎所有社交平台：网络论坛、Matrix服务器、私人游戏服务器（公共游戏服务器属于A类）、博客等。

comments.author: catapart
comments.content: That stuff is so bizarre! I can understand how an advertiser might try to sneak an infomercial onto an ad campaign, and I can understand how it might be attempted on accident. But I can't understand why an ostensible ad platform would ever allow you to upload a 30 min. ad without lots of flags going up and needing some approval.
comments.content_cn: 这东西太奇怪了！我能理解广告商可能试图将商业广告悄悄植入广告活动，也能理解这可能是意外失误。但我无法理解，一个表面上的广告平台怎么会允许用户上传长达30分钟的广告，却没有触发大量警示标志或需要任何审核流程。

comments.author: akersten
comments.content: Behavioral (invisible) analytics alone is the secret trillion dollar industry that online advertisers want to distract you from by focusing on the morality of ad blocking.A good blocker should block many of those scripts too, but there's no stopping server-side analytics at scale.
comments.content_cn: 行为（隐形）分析本身就是一个价值万亿美元的隐秘产业，在线广告商试图通过强调广告拦截的道德问题来转移你的注意力。优秀的拦截器应该也能屏蔽许多这类脚本，但大规模服务器端分析是无法阻止的。

comments.author: kibwen
comments.content: > But how is the internet economy supposed to functionIf the existence of a given industry requires the annihilation of individual privacy and the elimination of free thought, then that industry does not deserve to exist. Kill the ad industry.
comments.content_cn: 但如果互联网经济要如何运转？如果一个行业的存在必须以抹杀个人隐私和消除自由思想为前提，那么这个行业就不该存在。消灭广告业。

comments.author: matthewfcarlson
comments.content: Nothing makes me quite as irrationally angry as a 30 second ad on a one minute video
comments.content_cn: 没有什么比一分钟的视频前插播三十秒广告更让我莫名火大的了。

comments.author: shuntress
comments.content: The problem is not ads. The problem is SPAM.There are plenty of legitimately well-intentioned ads that can connect someone who needs a good/service with someone that supplies it and everyone wins.The problem is that we use a nearly totally free unregulated market where anyone can advertise anything anywhere.edit: I'm not saying we should necessarily try to optimize for good ads over bad ads or even assuming that is possible. I would settle for just somehow reducing the total volume of ads to help make email, snail main, voice mail, and other methods of communication more usable.
comments.content_cn: 问题不在于广告本身，而在于垃圾信息。许多出于善意、合法合规的广告能够将需要某种产品或服务的人与提供方联系起来，实现双赢。问题在于我们使用的是一个几乎完全免费且缺乏监管的市场，任何人都可以在任何地方宣传任何内容。编辑补充：我并不是说我们必须尝试优化广告质量，甚至不认为这一定可行。我只希望能以某种方式减少广告总量，让电子邮件、传统邮件、语音信箱及其他通讯方式变得更实用。

comments.author: charlieyu1
comments.content: As much as I hate ads, if you don’t make yourself known to potential customers you’re very screwed
comments.content_cn: 虽然我讨厌广告，但如果不让潜在客户知道你，那可就麻烦大了。

comments.author: kibwen
comments.content: Furiously seconded. Ads are just a tax that we pay both with our attention and then with our wallets. Every dollar that a company forks over to Google is a dollar they recoup by passing the costs on to you, for absolutely no benefit whatsoever to the product you're paying for. Destroy this heinous rent-seeking industry.
comments.content_cn: 强烈附议。广告就是一种税，我们既付出注意力又掏钱买单。企业每付给谷歌一美元，都会通过把成本转嫁给你来收回，而这对你花钱购买的产品毫无益处。摧毁这个可憎的寻租产业。

comments.author: serial_dev
comments.content: Even as a consumer I am legitimately happy that I’ve seen ads for some products.Now sure, it probably happens about once a quarter, and for that I watched probably hundreds if not thousands of ads, so was it worth it, I don’t know, probably not.
comments.content_cn: 即便作为一名普通消费者，我也确实因为看到某些产品的广告而感到高兴。当然，这种情况大概一个季度才出现一次，而为此我可能观看了成百上千条广告。所以这到底值不值得？我不知道，或许并不值得。

comments.author: al_borland
comments.content: As much as I hate ads, I don’t know that it’s so simple.There are products that do solve legitimate problems people have. Maybe there is less of that now, but in this past this was very true, and advertising helped make people aware that solutions to their problems have been developed. The first washing machine, for example.The problem comes when the advertisement manufacturers problems that didn’t previously exist.
comments.content_cn: 虽然我讨厌广告，但事情并非那么简单。有些产品确实能解决人们实际存在的问题。也许现在这类产品变少了，但过去确实如此，广告帮助人们了解到针对他们问题的解决方案已经被开发出来。比如第一台洗衣机。问题在于广告开始制造原本不存在的问题。

comments.author: catapart
comments.content: I did not claim, nor imply, that ads do not work on me. In fact, I alluded to the opposite in my closing line: " In five seconds, you can remind me that dawn exists, fulfilling the main purpose of the ad[...]"> the main purpose of the adI recognize that showing me the name of the product is the most valuable part of an ad, by far. It's entirely about repetition which breeds enough familiarity for trial, and enough personal affirmation if the trial is a positive one.But, that aside, if I'm looking for a skip button before the 5 seconds is up, I either do not purchase the product (I'm not sold: I don't buy), or I'm already a purchaser of the product and I'm either a fan (Your ad didn't sell me: I was sold, beforehand) or I'm not (I'm not sold: I don't buy it anymore). It wasn't a statement about ads not working on me, it's a statement about a personal, practical response to ads that I am conciously aware of because I'm already looking for a skip button.
comments.content_cn:
我并未声称或暗示广告对我无效。事实上，我在结尾处暗示了相反的情况："五秒钟内，你可以提醒我黎明存在，这实现了广告的主要目的……" 我承认展示产品名称是广告最有价值的部分，关键在于通过重复建立足够熟悉度以促成试用，并在试用满意时强化个人认同。

但除此之外，如果我在五秒结束前就在寻找跳过按钮，那意味着要么我不会购买该产品（未被说服：我不买），要么我已是该产品的用户——可能是忠实用户（你的广告并未说服我：我早已认可），也可能不再购买（未被说服：我已不再购买）。这并非关于广告对我无效的论断，而是我个人对广告的实际反应——当我主动寻找跳过按钮时，这种反应是我清醒意识到的。

comments.author: catapart
comments.content: Just a hip-shot, not a considered position. When I hear "regulation", I think "threat". Either of violence (any physical touch), or financial garnishment. So, to me, ads that last longer than five seconds do not rise to the level of threatening anyone.But assuming that they did, the situation seems like one where there could be any number or ways of following the letter or the law, while flouting the spirit of it. I don't dare imagine the creative ways these people will come up with to make entertainment even worse than it already is. So for areas that seem to require miles and miles of caveats and very specific rule-making, my gut reaction is that the regulatory path isn't the right one until we can break down the scope into something that simple regulations can accommodate without loophole. Put more simply: if it seems like people will just find ways around the problem, my assumption is just that we're not targeting the right problem yet and we need to break it down further, if regulation is the right solution at all.But that is pretty assumptive, so - again - it's just a first feeling. Doesn't pass my vibe check.
comments.content_cn: 这只是一时直觉，并非深思熟虑的观点。每当我听到“监管”这个词，联想到的就是“威胁”——无论是暴力威胁（任何肢体接触）还是经济制裁。因此在我看来，超过五秒的广告根本谈不上对任何人构成威胁。但假设它们确实构成威胁，这种情况似乎属于那种有无数方法可以表面上遵守法律条文、实则践踏法律精神的情形。我不敢想象这些人会创造出什么新奇手段，把本已糟糕的娱乐体验变得更糟。所以对于那种需要长篇累牍的免责声明和极其具体规则制定的领域，我的本能反应是：在我们将监管范围分解到简单规则能够无缝覆盖之前，监管这条路并不正确。更直白地说：如果人们看起来总能找到规避问题的方法，我的判断就是——我们尚未找准问题的核心，需要进一步分解问题（假设监管确实是正确解决方案的话）。但这很大程度上是主观推测，所以重申一遍，这只是初步感受，经不起我的直觉检验。

comments.author: cm2012
comments.content: Its market distortionary and makes global advertisers have to customize for the local audience, some might not bother
comments.content_cn: 它具有市场扭曲性，迫使全球广告商必须针对本地受众进行定制，有些可能就不愿费这个劲了。

comments.author: simplicio
comments.content: Think the best argument against it is that it makes advertising less valuable, which in turn limits the how many "paid for with advertising" services will be available and how good those services will be.Especially in a developing country where consumers ability to pay for such things is going to be limited, that will presumably deprive some margin of the population of media/services that are currently ad supported.
comments.content_cn: 我认为反对它的最佳理由是，这会降低广告的价值，进而限制“由广告付费”服务的数量和质量。尤其是在发展中国家，消费者支付此类服务的能力有限，这可能会使一部分人无法获得目前由广告支持的媒体或服务。

comments.author: echelon
comments.content: Second order effects.Many advertisers may avoid advertising or lower their ad budgets. This means the tech platform makes less revenue. This means the platform and the video creator both make less revenue. This means less videos get created.All of these happen at the population level.I hate ads, but regulations that are for things that aren't public health (including mental health), anti-monopolization, etc. are probably bad for innovation and growth.You have to balance regulation and over-regulation.
comments.content_cn: 二阶效应。许多广告商可能会避免投放广告或降低广告预算。这意味着科技平台的收入减少。平台和视频创作者的收入都会因此下降。最终导致视频产量减少。这些都是在整体层面发生的影响。我讨厌广告，但那些并非针对公共卫生（包括心理健康）、反垄断等领域的监管措施，可能不利于创新和增长。必须在监管与过度监管之间找到平衡。

posts.author: alexpadula
posts.title_cn: C语言最佳（2025）
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“C语言是否仍是最佳选择”展开。用户普遍认同C语言具有稳定、成熟、生态广泛等优势，尤其适合底层系统开发，许多现有项目（如SQLite）依赖其可靠性。有人认为新语言（如Rust、Zig）在HackerNews等平台被过度推崇，给开发者带来不必要的选择压力；也有用户指出，新语言解决了C语言的安全性和现代性缺陷，值得关注。讨论中提到，C语言委员会保守的更新策略虽使其“老旧”，却确保了稳定性，而部分语言频繁更新反而影响长期维护。分歧在于：一方坚持C不可替代，另一方认为Rust等语言已能满足跨平台和安全性需求。此外，有用户提及Ada可能符合类似C的稳定要求，但未形成共识。整体上，社区肯定C的历史地位，但对新兴语言的价值存在不同看法。

comments.author: baranul
comments.content: Every project and programmer shouldn't feel they have to justify their choice not to use Rust (or Zig), who seem to be strangely and disproportionately pushed on Hacker News and specific other social media platforms. This includes the pressure, though a bit less in recent years, to use OOP.If they are getting good results with C and without OOP, and people like the product, then those from outside the project shouldn't really have any say on it. It's their project.
comments.content_cn: 每个项目和程序员都不应觉得必须为自己选择不使用Rust（或Zig）而辩解，这些语言在Hacker News及其他特定社交媒体平台上似乎被异常且不成比例地推崇。这还包括使用面向对象编程的压力，尽管近年来这种压力有所减轻。如果他们用C语言且不采用面向对象编程取得了良好成果，并且用户喜欢他们的产品，那么项目之外的人实际上不应对此指手画脚。这是他们自己的项目。

comments.author: publicdebates
comments.content: > Rust needs to mature a little more, stop changing so fast, and move further toward being old and boring.One of the very strange things about C is that it is designed by a committee that is inherently conservative and prefers to not add new features, especially if they have any chance of breaking any compatibility. This seems necessary before Rust ever becomes an old, boring language.But I don't see Rust ever going in such a direction. It seems fundamentally opposed to Rust's philosophy, which is to find the best solution to the problems it's trying to solve, at any cost, including breaking compatibility, at least to some degree.
comments.content_cn: Rust需要更成熟一些，放缓快速变革的步伐，进一步朝着稳定保守的方向发展。C语言的一个非常奇特之处在于，它由本质上保守且倾向于不增加新特性的委员会设计，特别是当这些特性有可能破坏兼容性时。在Rust成为一门稳定保守的语言之前，这似乎是必要的。但我并不认为Rust会朝这个方向发展。这似乎从根本上违背了Rust的哲学，即不惜一切代价（包括在某种程度上破坏兼容性）为其试图解决的问题寻找最佳解决方案。

comments.content: Well, can't argue with it. Ruby and Python are written mostly in C underneath.Many try to replace C. All failed.I'd love to see a language that could satisfy both high end needs and low need needs. I would not know how such a language would look though.
comments.content_cn: 确实，这一点无可辩驳。Ruby和Python底层主要由C语言编写。许多人试图取代C语言，但都失败了。我很想看到一种既能满足高端需求又能满足低端需求的语言，不过我也想象不出这样的语言会是什么样子。

comments.author: simonw
comments.content:
"In a more complete build, SQLite also uses library routines like malloc() and free() and operating system interfaces for opening, reading, writing, and closing files."Whoa. TIL there's a minimal
build of SQLite that doesn't even need malloc() and free() !Presumably for embedded devices. I'd love to see examples of that being used in the wild.

comments.author: enricozb
comments.content: The final comments in this text seem sobering and indicate an openness to change. I worked recently on a project to migrate RediSearch to Rust, and this was partially motivated by a decent number of recent CVEs. If SQLite doesn't have this problem, then there needs to be some other strong argument for moving to Rust.I also think it's important to have really solid understandings (which can take a few decades I imagine) to understand the bounds of what Rust is good at. For example, I personally think it's unclear how good Rust can be for GUI applications.
comments.content_cn: 这段文本的最终评论显得发人深省，并显示出对变革的开放态度。我最近参与了一个将RediSearch迁移到Rust的项目，部分原因是近期出现了相当数量的常见漏洞披露。如果SQLite不存在这个问题，那么转向Rust就需要其他更有力的理由。此外，我认为真正扎实地理解Rust的适用边界至关重要（这可能需要几十年的时间来积累）。例如，我个人认为Rust在图形用户界面应用方面的潜力尚不明确。

comments.author: epolanski
comments.content: > The C language is old and boring. It is a well-known and well-understood language.This is such an under appreciated feature.I'm tired of languages that just keep adding and adding to a language.Work on the standard library or ecosystem, but stop changing the language otherwise you'll never end up anywhere because there is always going to be something that would benefit from some love.Hell, I'd say the same is true for many libraries.
comments.content_cn: C语言古老而乏味，它是一种广为人知且易于理解的语言。这一特性常被严重低估。我厌倦了那些不断堆砌新特性的语言。请专注于完善标准库或生态系统，别再改动语言本身了——否则永远无法抵达终点，因为总会有某些部分需要改进。说真的，我认为许多库也同样如此。

comments.author: WhyNotHugo
comments.content: > Nearly all systems have the ability to call libraries written in C. This is not true of other implementation languages.This is no longer true. Rust, Zig and likely others satisfy this requirements.> Safe languages usually want to abort if they encounter an out-of-memory (OOM) situation. SQLite is designed to recover gracefully from an OOM. It is unclear how this could be accomplished in the current crop of safe languages.This is a major annoyance in the rust stdlib. Too many interfaces can panic (and not just in case of an OOM), and some of them don’t even document this.
comments.content_cn:
几乎所有系统都能调用用C语言编写的库。其他实现语言则不具备这种能力。但现在情况已不同，Rust、Zig等语言很可能已满足这一要求。

安全语言在遇到内存不足（OOM）情况时通常希望中止运行。而SQLite的设计目标是从OOM中优雅恢复。目前主流的安全语言似乎难以实现这种机制。这在Rust标准库中尤为明显——过多接口可能触发恐慌（不仅限于OOM情况），且部分接口甚至未在文档中说明此风险。

comments.author: thisislife2
comments.content: From what they have written, the only other language that meets their requirement seems to be Ada:1. Stability: Ada is an "old and boring" language (aka stable and reliable - the first standard for the language was issued in 1983 and created for the Defence industry) - https://learn.adacore.com/courses/intro-to-ada/chapters/intr...2. Compatibility: Interoperability features is built-in, allowing you to create Ada libraries that can be used with other languages - https://piembsystech.com/interfacing-ada-programming-with-c-...3. Embedded Programming: Ada has been designed for embedded programming and the language includes constructs for directly manipulating hardware, for example, and direct interaction with assembly language. - https://learn.adacore.com/courses/intro-to-embedded-sys-prog...4. Ada supports processes / suites to comply with Branch coverage in ISO 26262 ( https://github.com/NVIDIA/spark-process ) and Decision coverage in DO-178C ( https://learn.adacore.com/booklets/adacore-technologies-for-... ).5. Ada has features supporting memory safety to avoid many memory issues in the first place ( https://www.adacore.com/blog/memory-safety-in-ada-and-spark-... ) and using its exception handling and programming techniques (like pre-allocating "guard" memory) can allow Ada programs to tackle fringe OOM errors.6. Performance: Ada is built for systems programming, is just as fast as C ( https://learn.adacore.com/courses/Ada_For_The_Embedded_C_Dev... ), with the added bonus of "modern" programming features that can generate more "reliable" code
comments.content_cn:

4. Ada支持符合ISO 26262分支覆盖率的流程/套件（https://github.com/NVIDIA/spark-process）以及DO-178C决策覆盖率（https://learn.adacore.com/booklets/adacore-technologies-for-...）。

6. 性能：Ada为系统编程构建，速度与C语言相当（https://learn.adacore.com/courses/Ada_For_The_Embedded_C_Dev...），并额外具备……

comments.author: nu11ptr
comments.content: I am a pretty serious "Rustacean", but I like to think "for the right reasons". A rewrite in Rust of the main project would make very little sense, unless there is some objective the project wants that can't be met with C (see below). This person presents a well thought out case on why it makes little sense to rewrite, especially in the final section. Rust is great for many things, but when you have something old that is already so well tested and accessible on all sorts of obscure platforms, it makes little sense to rewrite, and the likely result would be more bugs, not less, at least in the short term.All that said, some have found reasons to rewrite in Rust, and are currently working on that: https://turso.tech/blog/introducing-limbo-a-complete-rewrite...
comments.content_cn: 我算是个相当认真的"Rust语言爱好者"，但自认为是"出于正当理由"。用Rust重写这个主要项目意义不大，除非项目存在C语言无法实现的目标（详见下文）。作者在最后部分特别阐述了为何重写（尤其是用Rust重写）缺乏合理性，论证过程相当周密。Rust在很多方面确实出色，但对于那些历经考验、能在各种冷门平台上稳定运行的成熟项目而言，重写不仅意义有限，更可能在短期内引入更多而非更少的错误。话虽如此，确实有人找到了用Rust重写的理由并正在推进相关工作：https://turso.tech/blog/introducing-limbo-a-complete-rewrite...

comments.author: tialaramex
comments.content: > But no other language claims to be faster than C for general-purpose programming, because none are.The "faster than C for general-purpose programming" is a pretty woolly claim so I'm not entirely surprised nobody claims that, but equally I think to be sure that "because none are" would need some serious caveats to make it true.In particular you're going to have to say you think it doesn't matter how much developer time is needed. A project where C programmers spend five hours to make it run in 4 seconds is in this caveat "20% faster" than a project where Alt Lang programmers spend five minutes to make it run in 5 seconds - because only those seconds count. This is not how the real world works so it's a pretty nasty caveat.
comments.content_cn: 但没有其他语言声称在通用编程上比C语言更快，因为确实没有。所谓“在通用编程上比C语言更快”是个相当模糊的说法，所以没人这样宣称我并不完全意外，但同样我认为，要确信“因为确实没有”这一点，需要加上一些重要的限定条件才能成立。特别是，你必须声明你认为开发人员需要投入多少时间无关紧要。按照这种限定，一个C程序员花五小时让程序在4秒内运行的项目，比另一个替代语言程序员花五分钟让程序在5秒内运行的项目“快20%”——因为只有那些秒数才算数。现实世界并非如此运作，所以这是个相当苛刻的限定条件。

comments.author: jonny_eh
comments.content: > So, for example, Android applications written in Java are able to invoke SQLite (through an adaptor). comments.author: lordnacho
comments.content: The bit about why not OOP seems a bit old. I think we're past a point where people are going for OOP as the default shape of code.Overall, it makes sense. C is a systems language, and a DB is a system abstraction. You shouldn't need to build a deep hierarchy of abstractions on top of C, just stick with the lego blocks you have.If the project had started in 2016, maybe they would have gone for c++, which is a different beast from what it was pre-2011.Similarly, you might write SQLite in Rust if you started today.
comments.content_cn: 关于为何不采用面向对象编程的讨论似乎有些过时了。我认为我们已经过了那种将面向对象编程作为代码默认形态的阶段。总的来说，这说得通。C语言是一种系统语言，而数据库是一种系统抽象。你不需要在C语言之上构建复杂的抽象层次，只需利用现有的基础模块即可。如果这个项目始于2016年，或许他们会选择C++，这与2011年之前的C++已大不相同。同样地，如果今天从头开始，你可能会用Rust来编写SQLite。

comments.author: Ragnarork
comments.content: > Libraries written in C++ or Java can generally only be used by applications written in the same language. It is difficult to get an application written in Haskell or Java to invoke a library written in C++. On the other hand, libraries written in C are callable from any programming language.Not saying they should have picked C++ but that's a bit untrue. It's quite easy given some thought into the API to invoke C++ code in basically any language which can invoke C code, since you can wrap a C++ implementation in a C interface. I've done it multiple time throughout my career (that ended up being called from Python, Swift, Objective-C/C++, Swift, Java, and Kotlin).And as a side note, you don't have to do object-oriented programming in C++ if you don't want to.
comments.content_cn: 用C++或Java编写的库通常只能由相同语言编写的应用程序使用。很难让用Haskell或Java编写的应用程序调用用C++编写的库。另一方面，用C编写的库可以从任何编程语言调用。并不是说他们应该选择C++，但这有点不准确。只要在API设计上稍加考虑，基本上任何能调用C代码的语言都可以轻松调用C++代码，因为你可以用C接口包装C++实现。我在职业生涯中多次这样做过（最终被Python、Swift、Objective-C/C++、Swift、Java和Kotlin调用）。另外，如果你不想，你不必在C++中进行面向对象编程。

comments.author: pie_flavor
comments.content: The 'some degree' is pretty important, though. The Rust language undergoes backwards incompatible changes sometimes, but the Rust tools do not. The 2024 edition has breaking changes since the 2021 edition, but all compilers can compile all historical editions and will do so forever, and new language features are available in as many editions as possible, and editions can be mixed in a dependency tree, so you do not ever have to update your 2015 edition code for anything.
comments.content_cn: “一定程度”这一点相当重要。Rust语言有时会进行向后不兼容的更改，但Rust工具链不会。2024版相对2021版存在破坏性变更，但所有编译器都能编译所有历史版本且将永久保持此特性，新语言功能会尽可能在多个版本中提供支持，且依赖树中可以混合使用不同版本，因此您永远无需为任何原因更新2015版的代码。

comments.author: tialaramex
comments.content: Although Mozilla's reason to pay for Rust R&D was because of problems with C++ it's probably not most helpful to think of Rust (let alone F#) as an attempt to specifically fix those problems.C is a Worse is Better language (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worse_is_better). The bet is that if it's simpler to implement then the fact that what you're implementing isn't great will be dwarfed by that ease of implementation. And it worked for decades which is definitely a success.You can make a similar argument for Go, but not really for Rust. The other side of the Worse is Better coin is that maybe you could make the Right Thing™ instead.Because implementing C is so easy and implementing the Right Thing™ is very difficult, the only way this would compete is if almost nobody needs to implement the Right Thing™ themselves. In 1970 that's crazy, each Computer is fairly custom. But by 1995 it feels a lot less "out there", the Intel x86 ISA is everywhere, Tim's crap hypermedia experiment is really taking off. And when Rust 1.0 shipped in 2015 most people were able to use it without doing any implementation work, and the Right Thing™ is just better so why not?Now, for an existing successful project the calculation is very different, though note that Fish is an example of this working in terms of full throated RIIR. But in terms of whether you should use C for new work it comes out pretty strongly against C in my opinion as a fairly expert C programmer who hasn't written any C for years because Rust is better.
comments.content_cn:
尽管Mozilla资助Rust研发的初衷源于C++存在的问题，但将Rust（更不用说F#）单纯视为解决这些特定问题的尝试可能并不恰当。C语言属于“差中求优”型语言（https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Worse_is_better），其核心理念在于：只要实现足够简单，即使语言本身存在缺陷，这种简易性也能掩盖不足。这种策略数十年来行之有效，无疑是成功的。

类似逻辑可部分适用于Go语言，但对Rust则不尽然。“差中求优”理念的反面，是创造“完美方案”的可能性。由于C语言极易实现，而“完美方案”的实现难度极高，要让两者竞争，唯一途径是确保几乎无人需要亲自实现“完美方案”。在1970年这简直是天方夜谭——当时每台计算机都高度定制化。但到1995年情况已大不相同：英特尔x86指令集无处不在，蒂姆那个粗糙的超媒体实验正迅猛发展。当Rust 1.0于2015年发布时，多数人无需任何实现工作即可使用，而“完美方案”显然更具优势，何乐而不为？

对于现有成功项目而言，考量标准则截然不同——不过Fish项目完全采用RIIR（用Rust重写）策略的成功案例值得注意。就新项目是否应采用C语言的问题，作为一名多年未编写C代码的专业C程序员，我认为当前形势已明显不利于C语言……

comments.author: threethirtytwo
comments.content: Is there still pressure to use OOP? On Hacker News, at least, the trend seems to be moving in the opposite direction. There’s growing skepticism toward OOP, and that’s reflected in the popularity of languages like Rust and Zig, which are explicitly designed to push against traditional object-oriented patterns.That’s not to say OOP advocacy has disappeared from HN. It still exists, but it no longer feels dominant or ascendant. If anything, it feels like a legacy viewpoint maintained by a sizable but aging contingent rather than a direction the community is moving toward.Part of OOP’s staying power comes from what I’d call a cathartic trap. Procedural programming is intuitive and straightforward. OOP, by contrast, offers a new conceptual lens: objects, inheritance, polymorphism, and eventually design patterns. When someone internalizes this framework, there’s often a strong moment of “clicking” where complex software suddenly feels explainable and structured. That feeling of insight can be intoxicating. Design patterns, in particular, amplify this effect by making complexity feel principled and universally applicable.But this catharsis is easy to confuse with effectiveness. The emotional satisfaction of understanding a system is orthogonal to whether that system actually produces better outcomes. I’ve seen a similar dynamic in religion, where the Bible’s dense symbolism and internal coherence produce a powerful sense of revelation once everything seems to “fit” together. The feeling is real, but it doesn’t validate the underlying model.In practice, OOP often increases complexity and reduces modularity. This isn’t always obvious from inside the paradigm. It tends to become clear only after working seriously in other paradigms, where composition, data-oriented design, or functional approaches make the tradeoffs impossible to ignore.

comments.author: kibwen
comments.content: None of Rust's language features allocate; not arrays, not closures, not iterators. Everything is stack-allocated by default. Rust code doesn't malloc unless you use a library that calls malloc; in other words, exactly like C. Rust fully supports turning off the parts of the standard library that perform allocation, and this is precisely what embedded code and the Linux kernel does. So Rust already gives you full control.
comments.content_cn: Rust的语言特性均不涉及内存分配，无论是数组、闭包还是迭代器。默认情况下所有数据都分配在栈上。除非使用调用malloc的库，否则Rust代码不会执行malloc操作——这与C语言完全一致。Rust完全支持禁用标准库中执行内存分配的部分，这正是嵌入式代码和Linux内核所采用的方式。因此Rust已为您提供了完整的控制权。

posts.title: Opus 4.5 is not the normal AI agent experience that I have had thus far
posts.author: tbassetto
posts.title_cn: Opus 4.5并非我迄今为止所体验的常规AI智能体。
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕Opus 4.5等AI编程代理的实际能力与局限性展开。核心争议在于AI能否替代工程师处理真实世界的复杂开发任务。有人认为Opus 4.5在解决已知模式问题时表现惊艳，能快速生成可运行代码，尤其适合原型构建；也有用户指出它面对混乱数据、复杂系统或需要长期维护的场景时，仍会陷入错误路径且缺乏责任承担能力。讨论中提到，许多工程师担忧未经审计的AI生成代码存在安全隐患，且AI无法像人类一样对代码质量负责。虽然部分用户认为Claude Code等工具能通过学习代码库规范提升效率，但普遍共识是：当前AI更适合辅助原子化任务，而无法替代工程师在系统设计、技术债务管理和团队协作中的核心作用。

comments.author: multisport
comments.content: What bothers me about posts like this is: mid-level engineers are not tasked with atomic, greenfield projects. If all an engineer did all day was build apps from scratch, with no expectation that others may come along and extend, build on top of, or depend on, then sure, Opus 4.5 could replace them. The hard thing about engineering is not "building a thing that works", its building it the right way, in an easily understood way, in a way that's easily extensible.No doubt I could give Opus 4.5 "build be a XYZ app" and it will do well. But day to day, when I ask it "build me this feature" it uses strange abstractions, and often requires several attempts on my part to do it in the way I consider "right". Any non-technical person might read that and go "if it works it works" but any reasonable engineer will know that thats not enough.
comments.content_cn: 这类帖子让我困扰的地方在于：中级工程师的任务并非处理孤立的全新项目。如果一个工程师整天只负责从零开始构建应用，且不考虑他人后续可能需要扩展、在其基础上开发或依赖它，那么Opus 4.5确实可能取代他们。工程实践的难点不在于“做出能运行的东西”，而在于以正确的方式、易于理解的方式、便于扩展的方式构建它。毫无疑问，我可以让Opus 4.5“构建一个XYZ应用”，它会做得不错。但在日常工作中，当我要求它“为我构建这个功能”时，它常使用奇怪的抽象方式，往往需要我多次尝试才能让它以我认为“正确”的方式实现。非技术人员可能会觉得“能运行就行”，但任何合格的工程师都明白这远远不够。

comments.content: Opus 4.5 ate through my Copilot quota last month, and it's already halfway through it for this month. I've used it a lot, for really complex code.And my conclusion is: it's still not as smart as a good human programmer. It frequently got stuck, went down wrong paths, ignored what I told it to do to do something wrong, or even repeat a previous mistake I had to correct.Yet in other ways, it's unbelievably good. I can give it a directory full of code to analyze, and it can tell me it's an implementation of Kozo Sugiyama's dagre graph layout algorithm, and immediately identify the file with the error. That's unbelievably impressive. Unfortunately it can't fix the error. The error was one of the many errors it made during previous sessions.So my verdict is that it's great for code analysis, and it's fantastic for injecting some book knowledge on complex topics into your programming, but it can't tackle those complex problems by itself.Yesterday and today I was upgrading a bunch of unit tests because of a dependency upgrade, and while it was occasionally very helpful, it also regularly got stuck. I got a lot more done than usual in the same time, but I do wonder if it wasn't too much. Wasn't there an easier way to do this? I didn't look for it, because every step of the way, Opus's solution seemed obvious and easy, and I had no idea how deep a pit it was getting me into. comments.author: soulofmischief
comments.content: Opus 4.5 is currently helping me write a novel, comprehensive and highly performant programming language with all of the things I've ever wanted, done in exactly my opinionated way.This project would have taken me years of specialization and research to do right. Opus's strength has been the ability to both speak broadly and also drill down into low-level implementations.I can express an intent, and have some discussion back and forth around various possible designs and implementations to achieve my goals, and then I can be preparing for other tasks while Opus works in the background. I ask Opus to loop me in any time there are decisions to be made, and I ask it to clearly explain things to me.Contrary to losing skills, I feel that I have rapidly gained a lot of knowledge about low-level systems programming. It feels like pair programming with an agentic model has finally become viable.I will be clear though, it takes the steady hand of an experience and attentive senior developer + product designer to understand how to maintain constraints on the system that allow the codebase to grow in a way that is maintainable on the long-term. This is especially important, because the larger the codebase is, the harder it becomes for agentic models to reason holistically about large-scale changes or how new features should properly integrate into the system.If left to its own devices, Opus 4.5 will delete things, change specification, shirk responsibilities in lieu of hacky band-aids, etc. You need to know the stack well so that you can assist with debugging and reasoning about code quality and organization. It is not a panacea. But it's ground-breaking. This is going to be my most productive year in my life.On the flip side though, things are going to change extremely fast once large-scale, profitable infrastructure becomes easily replicable, and spinning up a targeted phishing campaign takes five seconds and a walk around the park. And our workforce will probably start shrinking permanently over the next few years if progress does not hit a wall.Among other things, I do predict we will see a resurgence of smol web communities now that independent web development is becoming much more accessible again, closer to how it when I first got into it back in the early 2000's.

comments.author: IgorPartola
comments.content: The thing is that CLI utilities code is probably easier to write for an LLM than most other things. In my experience an LLM does best with backend and terminal things. Anything that resembles boilerplate is great. It does well refactoring unit tests, wrapping known code in a CLI, and does decent work with backend RESTful APIs. Where it fails utterly is things like HTML/CSS layout, JavaScript frontend code for SPAs, and particularly real world UI stuff that requires seeing and interacting with a web page/app where things like network latency and errors, browser UI, etc. can trip it up. Basically when the input and output are structured and known an LLM will do well. When they are “look and feel” they fail and fail until they make the code unmaintainable.This experience for me is current but I do not normally use Opus so perhaps I should give it a try and figure out if it can reason around problems I myself do not foresee (for example a browser JS API quirk that I had never seen).

comments.author: FloorEgg
comments.content: There are two types of right/wrong ways to build: the context specific right/wrong way to build something and an overly generalized engineer specific right/wrong way to build things.I've worked on teams where multiple engineers argued about the "right" way to build something. I remember thinking that they had biases based on past experiences and assumptions about what mattered. It usually took an outsider to proactively remind them what actually mattered to the business case.I remember cases where a team of engineers built something the "right" way but it turned out to be the wrong thing. (Well engineered thing no one ever used)Sometimes hacking something together messily to confirm it's the right thing to be building is the right way. Then making sure it's secure, then finally paying down some technical debt to make it more maintainable and extensible.Where I see real silly problems is when engineers over-engineer from the start before it's clear they are building the right thing, or when management never lets them clean up the code base to make it maintainable or extensible when it's clear it is the right thing.There's always a balance/tension, but it's when things go too far one way or another that I see avoidable failures.
comments.content_cn:
构建事物存在两种正确/错误的方式：一种是针对具体情境的正确/错误构建方式，另一种是工程师过度泛化的特定正确/错误构建方式。我曾参与过一些团队，其中多位工程师为某事的“正确”构建方式争论不休。我记得当时认为他们基于过往经验和对关键要素的假设产生了偏见。通常需要局外人主动提醒他们业务案例真正需要关注的重点。

我记得有些案例中，工程师团队以“正确”方式构建了某物，结果却证明是错误的选择。（精心设计的产品无人使用）有时，草率拼凑原型来验证构建方向的正确性反而是恰当的做法。随后确保其安全性，最后通过偿还技术债务来提升可维护性和可扩展性。

真正荒谬的问题往往出现在两种极端情况：工程师在尚未明确构建方向时就过度设计，或是管理层在明确产品价值后仍不允许团队清理代码库以实现可维护和可扩展。平衡与张力始终存在，但当事情过度偏向某一极端时，本可避免的失败就会发生。

comments.author: Calavar
comments.content: There are multiple Python 3 interpreters written in JavaScript that were very likely included in the training data. For example [1] [2] [3]I once gave Claude (Opus 3.5) a problem that I thought was for sure too difficult for an LLM, and much to my surprise it spat  out a very convincing solution. The surprising part was I was already familiar with the solution - because it was almost a direct copy/paste (uncredited) from a blog post that I read only a few hours earlier. If I hadn't read that blog post, I would have been none the wiser that copy/pasting Claude's output would be potential IP theft. I would have to imagine that LLMs solve a lot of in-training-set problems this way and people never realize they are dealing with a copyright/licensing minefield.A more interesting and convincing task would be to write a Python 3 interpeter in JavaScript that uses register based bytecode instead of stack based, supports optimizing the bytecode by inlining procedures and constant folding, and never allocates memory (all work is done in a single user provided preallocated buffer). This would require integrating multiple disparate coding concepts and not regurgitating prior art from the training data[1] https://github.com/skulpt/skulpt[2] https://github.com/brython-dev/brython[3] https://github.com/yzyzsun/PyJS
comments.content_cn:
训练数据中很可能包含了多个用JavaScript编写的Python 3解释器，例如[1][2][3]。我曾给Claude（Opus 3.5）一个我认为对大型语言模型来说肯定过于困难的问题，令我非常惊讶的是，它给出了一个非常有说服力的解决方案。令人意外的是，我对这个解决方案已经很熟悉——因为它几乎是从我几小时前刚读过的一篇博客文章中直接复制粘贴而来（未注明出处）。如果我没读过那篇博客，我根本不会意识到复制粘贴Claude的输出可能构成知识产权盗窃。可以想象，大型语言模型很可能以这种方式解决了许多训练集中的问题，而人们从未意识到自己正身处版权/许可的雷区。

一个更有趣且更具说服力的任务是：用JavaScript编写一个Python 3解释器，要求使用基于寄存器的字节码而非基于栈的字节码，支持通过内联过程和常量折叠来优化字节码，且永不分配内存（所有操作均在用户提供的单一预分配缓冲区中完成）。这需要整合多种不同的编码概念，而不是简单复现训练数据中的现有技术。

[1] https://github.com/skulpt/skulpt
[2] https://github.com/brython-dev/brython
[3] https://github.com/yzyzsun/PyJS

comments.content_cn:
在我看来，大语言模型在编程方面的优势主要体现在以下几个方面，它们在这些任务上表现非常出色：  
- 单一脚本任务。任何能简化为单一脚本的工作。  
- 从零开始启动新项目。  
- 代码维护（包升级、旧代码处理等）。  
- 定义清晰且单一的任务。这与复杂度无关，有些任务可能非常复杂，但定义明确。  
如果你的工作属于以上范畴，它们会完成得非常出色（你的任务显然符合这一点）；但如果不属于，请做好准备，因为过程可能会很艰难。

posts.title: Stop Doom Scrolling, Start Doom Coding: Build via the terminal from your phone
posts.content: I used Tailscale, an old laptop, Claude Code, and Termius to code from my phone anywhere I have Internet connection.Great for parties where you rather be home tinkering.
posts.author: rbergamini27
posts.title_cn: 停止末日刷屏，开始末日编程：通过手机终端构建项目
posts.content_cn: 我利用Tailscale、一台旧笔记本电脑、Claude Code和Termius，实现了在任何有网络的地方都能用手机编程。这非常适合那些你宁愿在家摆弄技术却不得不参加聚会的场合。
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕“通过手机终端进行编程”这一核心话题展开。原帖作者分享了使用Tailscale、旧笔记本电脑、Claude Code和Termius等工具实现手机远程编程的经验，尤其适合在社交场合中“摸鱼”编码。

社区讨论中，用户观点多元。有人认为手机编程并非新鲜事，指出在部分国家因笔记本电脑稀缺，手机甚至是主要编程工具。也有用户指出，现有方案如GitHub移动端配合Copilot和Actions已能实现类似需求，但可能不适合生产环境。针对是否应通过电子邮件接口与Claude交互，存在分歧：一方认为邮件方式笨拙且反馈不及时，不如VPN方案直接可靠；另一方则建议可结合Telegram等平台构建机器人来执行命令，避免开放路由器端口。讨论中还提到，部分用户更倾向于在终端环境中完成所有开发部署流程，认为这比依赖云端服务更理想。

普遍共识是，手机编程在技术上可行且已有多种实践方式，但具体工具链和适用场景因人而异。

comments.author: analogpixel

comments.content: > Would an email interface to Claude code work better?No.> What is the downside to using email?Email is clunky and feedback is not immediate.> seems easier then getting a vpn working.Tailscale is easy for a dev to get going and very reliable. The author uses the Termius SSH app with Mosh, so it keeps the same SSH session going across device sleeps and disconnects. Tmux is helpful, too.I do exactly what the author is doing, except I use a $5 Linode VPS, instead of a Mac at home.He doesn't seem to be credited on this page, but I believe Pieter Levels (@levelsio) actually popularized this scheme. The author documents a nearly identical scheme.
comments.content_cn:

我的做法与作者完全相同，只是我使用5美元的Linode VPS，而非家中的Mac电脑。
此页面似乎未注明来源，但我认为实际上是Pieter Levels（@levelsio）推广了这种方案。作者记录了一套几乎完全相同的方案。

comments.author: godelski
comments.content: While I don't use the AI part I have a very similar scheme and it is one of the reasons I encourage people to live in the terminal.The idea is to create a modern "terminal"[0]My main computer is a Macbook Air, which I carry around with me. It's purpose is for: internet, using Microsoft products when I'm forced to, Zoom/meetings, and SSH (or Mosh).Most of my work is not done on this Macbook, instead I use it mostly as a terminal. I have a desktop that's sitting behind my TV so that it can be my TV and gaming system (yeah I know Monitor > TV. I'm a filthy casual and I don't care). I have a mouse connected to that computer and instead of using a keyboard I use ydotool (Wayland xdotool) with a shortcut on my iPhone or a script on my android phone or from my Macbook. I don't have to get up from the couch and I don't need a clunky wireless keyboard to clutter my livingroom.Additionally I have a few pis and an old android phone with Tailscale installed on them. That's come in handy before as a machine's been disconnected and so I couldn't ssh from outside. Also makes it really easy to do a jump if you want to keep a machine off Tailscale or you don't have full control (like my 3D printer).This setup is very natural feeling if you live in the terminal. I actually started doing this when I started doing HPC work. In a setting like that you're never sitting in front of the computer you're doing most of your work on so it kinda clicked "why was I restricting myself outside work?" Plus there's the side benefits of I always have access to my media, tools, and other stuff. You can do exactly the same thing with a phone but I like having a keyboard and the air is very lightweight and has a long battery life. Any netbook would have done the job tbh.[0] There's a reason they're called "terminal emulators" rather than just "terminals".
comments.content_cn: 虽然我不使用AI部分，但我有一个非常相似的方案，这也是我鼓励人们生活在终端里的原因之一。这个想法是创建一个现代的“终端”[0]。我的主要电脑是一台随身携带的Macbook Air，它的用途包括：上网、在不得已时使用微软产品、Zoom/会议以及SSH（或Mosh）。我的大部分工作并非在这台Macbook上完成，而是主要将其用作终端。我有一台放在电视后面的台式机，这样它既能当电视又能当游戏系统（我知道显示器比电视好，但我只是个随意的用户，并不在意）。那台电脑连接着鼠标，而我不用键盘，而是通过iPhone上的快捷指令、安卓手机上的脚本或Macbook来使用ydotool（Wayland版的xdotool）。这样我就不用从沙发上起身，也不需要笨重的无线键盘来弄乱客厅。此外，我还有几台树莓派和一部安装了Tailscale的旧安卓手机。之前有机器断开连接时，这些设备就派上了用场，让我无法从外部SSH。如果你想让某台机器不接入Tailscale，或者你没有完全控制权（比如我的3D打印机），这也让跳转变得非常容易。如果你生活在终端里，这种设置会感觉非常自然。实际上，我开始这样做是在从事高性能计算工作时。在那种环境下，你从来不会坐在你主要工作的电脑前，所以我突然意识到：“为什么要在工作之外限制自己呢？”再加上……

posts.title: enclose.horse
posts.author: DavidSJ
posts.title_cn: "enclose.horse"
posts.abstract: 该帖子围绕网页游戏“enclose.horse”展开讨论，核心话题涉及游戏设计、技术实现与数据收集伦理。多数用户赞赏游戏创意与趣味性，有人希望作者收集玩家数据以优化关卡设计并考虑商业化，也有用户指出应避免不必要的监控，强调纯粹娱乐的价值。技术方面，讨论中提到游戏使用Answer Set Programming（Clingo引擎）求解最优解，有用户认为处理更大网格可能是NP难题，并分享了在Factorio中类似问题的求解经验。此外，关于每日关卡更新时间，有用户建议统一全球时间以便跨时区竞争。社区共识在于对游戏趣味性的认可，主要分歧集中在数据收集是否合理，以及技术实现上最优解算法的可行性与效率。

comments.author: gorgoiler
comments.content: Great game, I love it!  I hope the author is collecting juicy analytics.  They would be useful if they ever want to bundle 100 levels in order of difficulty and release this as a Steam game (which I would absolutely buy!)I don’t think the gates should animate up into the air.  It breaks the visual logic of 2D for no benefit.  It’s subconsciously confusing to see a gate I place in one cell move to occupy pixels in the cell “above” it.I look forward to future days introducing new mechanics as well.  Can I suggest a few, based on dynamics?- Food!  The horse moves on every turn towards an attractor.  Have a hay bale / giant sugar cube in one corner fall off the back of a truck / helicopter :)  Horses start out dumb and move directly towards the goal before backtracking.  Smarter horses path find the shortest route to the goal.- Goals!  Now that the horse is moving, get the horse into a static horse box / cattle pen cell by strategically placing fences so that the path it takes towards the food involves walking onto the goal square.- Floods!  Water encroaches from the edges on a turn by turn basis.  Not only do you have to contain the horse, you also have to hold back the flood.
comments.content_cn:
很棒的游戏，我非常喜欢！希望开发者正在收集丰富的数据分析。如果未来他们想按难度打包100个关卡，在Steam上发布这款游戏（我绝对会购买！），这些数据会非常有用。我觉得栅栏的上升动画效果不太合适，它毫无必要地破坏了2D画面的视觉逻辑，看到放置在某个单元格的栅栏移动到“上方”单元格的像素区域，会让人下意识感到困惑。

我也期待未来更新能引入新机制。基于游戏动态，我可以提几个建议吗？

- 食物机制！让马每回合朝着吸引物移动。比如让角落里的干草捆/巨型方糖从卡车或直升机上掉落。马起初会笨拙地直接冲向目标，之后才折返；更聪明的马则会寻找最短路径抵达目标。

- 目标机制！既然马开始移动了，可以通过策略性放置围栏，使马在走向食物的路径中踏入静态的马厩/畜栏单元格，从而达成目标。

comments.author: Scaevolus
comments.content:
The site uses Answer Set Programming with the Clingo engine to compute the optimal solutions for smaller grids. Maximizing grids like this is probably NP-hard.Note that traditional SAT and SMT solvers are quite inefficient at computing flood-fills.The ASP specifications it uses to compute optimal solutions are surprisingly short and readable, and look like:  #const budget=11.
  horse(4,4).
  cell(0,0).
  boundary(0,0).
  cell(0,1).
  boundary(0,1).
  % ...truncated for brevity...
  cell(3,1).
  water(3,1).
  % ...
  
  % Adjacent cells (4-way connectivity)
  adj(R,C, R+1,C) :- cell(R,C), cell(R+1,C).
  adj(R,C, R-1,C) :- cell(R,C), cell(R-1,C).
  adj(R,C, R,C+1) :- cell(R,C), cell(R,C+1).
  adj(R,C, R,C-1) :- cell(R,C), cell(R,C-1).
  
  % Walkable = not water
  walkable(R,C) :- cell(R,C), not water(R,C).
  
  % Choice: place wall on any walkable cell except horse and cherries
  { wall(R,C) } :- walkable(R,C), not horse(R,C), not cherry(R,C).
  
  % Budget constraint (native counting - no bit-blasting!)
  :- #count { R,C : wall(R,C) } > budget.
  
  % Reachability from horse (z = enclosed/reachable cells)
  z(R,C) :- horse(R,C).
  z(R2,C2) :- z(R1,C1), adj(R1,C1, R2,C2), walkable(R2,C2), not wall(  R2,C2).
  
  % Horse cannot reach boundary (would escape)
  :- z(R,C), boundary(R,C).
  
  % Maximize enclosed area (cherries worth +3 bonus = 4 total)
  #maximize { 4,R,C : z(R,C), cherry(R,C) ; 1,R,C : z(R,C), not cherry(  R,C) }.
  
  % Only output wall positions
  #show wall/2.
comments.content_cn:
该网站使用答案集编程配合Clingo引擎来计算较小网格的最优解。对此类网格进行最大化处理很可能是NP难问题。需要注意的是，传统SAT和SMT求解器在计算泛洪填充时效率较低。其用于计算最优解的ASP规范出奇地简洁且可读性强，示例如下：

#const budget=11.
horse(4,4).
cell(0,0).
boundary(0,0).
cell(0,1).
boundary(0,1).
% ...此处省略部分内容...
cell(3,1).
water(3,1).
% ...

% 相邻单元格（四向连通性）
adj(R,C, R+1,C) :- cell(R,C), cell(R+1,C).
adj(R,C, R-1,C) :- cell(R,C), cell(R-1,C).
adj(R,C, R,C+1) :- cell(R,C), cell(R,C+1).
adj(R,C, R,C-1) :- cell(R,C), cell(R,C-1).

% 可通行区域 = 非水域
walkable(R,C) :- cell(R,C), not water(R,C).

% 选择：可在除马和樱桃外的任何可通行单元格放置围墙
{ wall(R,C) } :- walkable(R,C), not horse(R,C), not cherry(R,C).

% 预算约束（原生计数 - 无需位爆破！）
:- #count { R,C : wall(R,C) } > budget.

% 从马出发的可达性（z = 被围区域/可达单元格）
z(R,C) :- horse(R,C).
z(R2,C2) :- z(R1,C1), adj(R1,C1, R2,C2), walkable(R2,C2), not wall(R2,C2).

% 马不能到达边界（否则会逃脱）
:- z(R,C), boundary(R,C).

% 最大化围合区域（樱桃奖励+3分，总计4分）
#maximize { 4,R,C : z(R,C), cherry(R,C) ; 1,R,C : z(R,C), not cherry(R,C) }.

% 仅输出围墙位置
#show wall/2.

posts.title: I/O is no longer the bottleneck? (2022)
posts.author: benhoyt
posts.title_cn: I/O 不再是瓶颈了吗？（2022）
posts.abstract: 该讨论围绕“I/O是否仍是性能瓶颈”展开。有人认为现代CPU单核性能受限于内存带宽，例如x86芯片约为6GB/s，而苹果M芯片可达20GB/s，但广告宣传的“200GB/s”通常是总内存带宽，实际单核难以饱和。也有用户指出，当前硬件性能已大幅提升，但软件设计仍受传统机械硬盘时代假设的束缚，例如fsync()速度依然较慢，且云环境中I/O可能因计费策略受到限制。讨论中提到，部分芯片（如苹果M系列）需借助集成GPU才能充分利用统一内存带宽，而CPU核心单独工作难以实现峰值吞吐。分歧点在于对单核带宽极限的评估，有用户认为引用的数据偏低，并提供了单核可达25GB/s的测试案例。共识在于，尽管存储硬件进步显著，但软件架构和云服务计费模式可能使I/O在实际场景中仍构成瓶颈。

comments.author: eliasdejong
comments.content: Increasingly the performance limit for modern CPUs is the amount of data you can feed through a single core: basically memcpy() speed. On most x86 cores the limit is around 6 GB/s and about 20 GB/s for Apple M chips.When you see advertised numbers like '200 GB/s' that is total memory bandwidth, or all cores combined. For individual cores, the limit will still be around 6 GB/s.This means even if you write a perfect parser, you cannot go faster. This limit also applies to (de)serializing data like JSON and Protobuf, because those formats must typically be fully parsed before a single field can be read.If however you use a zero-copy format, the CPU can skip data that it doesn't care about, so you can 'exceed' the 6 GB/s limit.The Lite³ serialization format I am working on aims to exploit exactly this, and is able to outperform simdjson by 120x in some benchmarks as a result: https://github.com/fastserial/lite3
comments.content_cn:
现代CPU的性能瓶颈日益体现在单核能够处理的数据量上：本质上就是memcpy()的速度。在大多数x86架构核心上，这一限制约为每秒6GB，而苹果M芯片则能达到每秒20GB左右。当你看到诸如"每秒200GB"这样的宣传数据时，那指的是总内存带宽，即所有核心的合计值。对于单个核心而言，限制仍将维持在每秒6GB左右。

这意味着即使你编写出完美的解析器，也无法突破这一速度上限。该限制同样适用于JSON和Protobuf等数据的（反）序列化过程，因为这些格式通常需要完整解析后才能读取单个字段。

然而，如果采用零拷贝格式，CPU可以跳过不关心的数据，从而"突破"每秒6GB的限制。我正在开发的Lite³序列化格式正是为了充分利用这一特性，在某些基准测试中其性能甚至能超越simdjson达120倍：https://github.com/fastserial/lite3

comments.author: zozbot234
comments.content: On quite a few recent chips (including, AIUI, Apple M series) you can only saturate memory bandwidth by resorting to the iGPU (which has access to unified memory), CPU cores on their own won't do it.  It means that using the iGPU as a blitter for huge in-memory transfers and for all throughput-limited computation (including such things as parallel parsing or de/compression workloads) is now the technically advisable choice, provided that this can be arranged.> If however you use a zero-copy format, the CPU can skip data that it doesn't care about, so you can 'exceed' the 6 GB/s limit.Of course the "skipping" is by cachelines.  A cacheline is effectively a self-contained block of data from a memory throughput perspective, once you've read any part of it the rest comes for free.
comments.content_cn: 在不少近期芯片（据我所知包括苹果M系列）上，只有借助集成显卡（可访问统一内存）才能完全利用内存带宽，仅靠CPU核心无法实现。这意味着，若条件允许，技术上建议采用集成显卡作为大容量内存传输的位块搬运器，并处理所有受吞吐量限制的计算任务（包括并行解析或压缩/解压等工作负载）。> 但若使用零拷贝格式，CPU可跳过不关心的数据，从而“突破”6GB/s的限制。当然这种“跳过”是以缓存行为单位的。从内存吞吐角度看，缓存行实质上是独立的数据块——只要读取其中任意部分，剩余内容便可无额外开销地获取。

posts.title: How Y Combinator made it smart to trust founders
posts.author: spacemarine1
posts.title_cn: Y Combinator如何让信任创始人成为明智之举
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Y Combinator（YC）风险投资机构“信任创始人”的投资哲学展开。核心话题是探讨这种信任模式的有效性及其与军事“任务式指挥”理念的相似性，并延伸到当前AI投资热潮的影响。

社区观点多元。有用户将YC的策略类比为军事上的“任务式指挥”，认为在动态环境中，赋予创始人高度自主权是明智的，但这需要创始人与投资机构目标高度一致且能力出众。也有用户指出，这种模式的成功依赖于创始人的诚信与能力，并质疑风险投资过去为何不普遍采用此方式。讨论中提到，有观点认为永远不应轻信有利害关系的人，暗示了对创始人完全信任的潜在风险。

关于当前趋势，存在分歧。有用户担忧YC近期优先投资AI领域会动摇其原有的“信任创始人”模式。也有用户认为AI技术（如用于游戏开发）恰恰赋能了小而精的团队，符合YC支持优秀创始人的逻辑。共识在于，许多用户认同在“零利率时代”，风险资本急于投放，部分创始人可能因此迎合投资者，这影响了信任的基础。

comments.author: intalentive

But in more static or settled market environments it may be wiser (for investors) to focus elsewhere and restrict founder autonomy. We see this pretty commonly with successful founders who get "phased out" and replaced with more experienced managers.I wonder how much this sort of "distributed decision-making" has been formalized and studied.
comments.content_cn: 这体现了"任务式指挥"的军事原则，即赋予下属执行命令的广泛自主权。但这需要高度的目标一致性和执行能力，这也解释了为何YC更看重创始人而非产品或创意本身。在环境多变、地域条件敏感且指挥链存在"网络延迟"的情况下，这种模式是合理的。但在相对稳定或成熟的市场环境中，投资者或许更应关注其他方面并限制创始人的自主权。我们常看到成功创始人被"逐步淘汰"，由经验更丰富的管理者取代的现象。不知这类"分布式决策"模式已有多少系统化的研究和实践。

posts.title: Show HN: Prism.Tools – Free and privacy-focused developer utilities
posts.content:
Hi HN, I'm Barry and I've built Prism.Tools (https://blgardner.github.io/prism.tools/) – a collection of client-side developer utilities that respect your privacy.Many of these tools were used way back in the days when I ran a BBS and started my communities first ISP, serving three local communities with Dial-Up Internet, Web Hosting etc. The tools have been refined to reflect the changes in tech since then and designed for the Novice and Pro alike. As I locate more tools others may find useful I will refine and add them to the collection. Use them, Share them, or not. They will be here if you need them...40+ dev tools (JSON formatters, regex tester, base64 encoder, Git command helper, etc.) that run entirely in your browser.
Zero tracking, zero analytics, zero data collection – everything processes locally.
Self-contained HTML files with no build process or frameworks.I realized I had a lot of tools/utilities I've built over the years for my own use. I lothe having to 'sign-up' just to access/use simple utilities that I can create myself. I've refined them and put them in one safe place so I could easily access them if/when needed. I decided to make them available via Github Pages for anyone that may find them useful. Prism.Tools is the result.Each tool is a standalone HTML file with embedded CSS and JavaScript. No frameworks, no npm packages, no build steps – just open the file and it works.The entire toolset:- 100% client-side processing – your data never leaves your browser.- No external dependencies except for specific libraries from cdnjs.cloudflare.com (marked.js for markdown, exifr for image metadata, etc.)- Consistent dark UI – every tool follows the same design language for familiarity.- Vanilla JS where possible – only reaching for Public CDN Resources when necessary.The constraint of "single HTML file" was intentional. It forces simplicity and ensures tools remain maintainable. It also means users can inspect, modify, or self-host any tool trivially.These tools have helped me with debugging production issues, Quick formatting tasks, learning Git commands (the Git command helper has been particularly helpful)Just visit https://blgardner.github.io/prism.tools/ and try any tool. No signup, no install.What tools are missing that you find yourself needing?
Any performance issues with specific tools?
UI/UX friction points?All tools follow the same privacy-first philosophy...
Your data stays in your browser. No accounts, no tracking, no servers processing your information.
The project is also a demonstration that you don't always need React, Vue, or complex build pipelines – sometimes vanilla JavaScript in a single HTML file is exactly the right tool for the job.Vanilla JavaScript (ES6+)
CSS3 with CSS Grid
Minimal external libraries: marked.js, exifr, highlight.js, sql-formatter (all from CDN)
No frameworks, no bundlers, no npm
Hosted on Github PagesHappy to answer questions about the technical implementation, design decisions, or specific tools!All tools are inspectable – just view source on any page to see exactly how they work!

posts.title: Video Game Websites in the early 00s
posts.author: klaussilveira
posts.title_cn: 00年代初期的电子游戏网站
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕21世纪初的视频游戏网站展开，核心话题是用户对早期游戏网站及粉丝站点的怀旧与评价。多数用户表达了对当时独特网站设计、社区氛围和游戏文化的怀念，认为这些站点充满个性与创意，例如有人提到Planet Quake、Blues News等站点，也有用户分享通过GeoCities、游戏修改团队结识朋友的经历。

讨论中形成一定共识，即早期游戏网站因设计多样、社区紧密而被视为黄金时期，而现今许多站点已被广告充斥的通用wiki取代。同时存在分歧点：部分用户认为当前“粉丝文化”变得充满毒性，宁愿独自享受游戏而避开社群讨论；也有用户指出技术如HTML图像映射等元素值得复兴，以重现当年的视觉创意。整体上，讨论呈现出对早期网络自由、探索精神的 nostalgia，以及对当前网络环境变迁的不同感受。

posts.title: Tell HN: I write and ship code ~20–50x faster than I did 5 years ago
posts.content:
I’ve been meaning to write this up because it’s been surprisingly repeatable, and I wish someone had described it to me earlier.Over the last year or so, my development speed relative to my own baseline from ~2019 is easily 20x, sometimes more. Not because I type faster, or because I cut corners, but because I changed how I use AI.The short version: I don’t use AI inside my editor. I use two AIs in parallel, in the browser, with full context.Here’s the setup.I keep two tabs open:One AI that acts as a “builder”. It gets a lot of context and does the heavy lifting.One AI that acts as a reviewer. It only sees diffs and tries to find mistakes.That’s it. No plugins, no special tooling. Just browser tabs and a terminal.The important part is context. Instead of asking for snippets, I paste entire files or modules and explain the goal. I ask the AI to explain the approach first, including tradeoffs, before it writes code. That forces me to stay in control of architecture instead of accepting a blob I don’t understand.A typical flow looks like this:1. Paste several related files (often across languages).2. Describe the change I want and ask for an explanation of options. Read and summarize concepts, wikipedia, etc.3. Pick an approach. Have extensive conversations about trade-offs, concepts, adversarial security etc. Find ways to do things that the OS allows.4. Let the AI implement it across all files.5. Copy the diff into the second AI and ask it to look for regressions, missing arguments, or subtle breakage.6. Fix whatever it finds.Ship.The second AI catches a lot of things I would otherwise miss when moving fast. Things like “you changed this call signature but didn’t update one caller” or “this default value subtly changed behavior”.What surprised me is how much faster cross-stack work gets. Stuff that used to stall because it crossed boundaries (Swift → Obj-C → JS, or backend → frontend) becomes straightforward because the AI can reason across all of it at once.I’m intentionally strict about “surgical edits”. I don’t let the AI rewrite files unless that’s explicitly the task. I ask for exact lines to add or change. That keeps diffs small and reviewable.This is very different from autocomplete-style tools. Those are great for local edits, but they still keep you as the integrator across files. This approach flips that: you stay the architect and reviewer, the AI does the integration work, and a second AI sanity-checks it.Costs me about $40/month total. The real cost is discipline: always providing context, always reviewing diffs, and never pasting code you don’t understand.I’m sharing this because it’s been a genuine step-change for me, not a gimmick. Happy to answer questions about limits, failure modes, or where this breaks down.Here is a wiki-type overview I put together for our developers on our team:
https://community.intercoin.app/t/ai-assisted-development-playbook-how-we-ship-faster-without-breaking-things/2950
posts.author: EGreg
posts.title_cn: "告诉HN：我现在编写和交付代码的速度大约是5年前的20到50倍"
posts.content_cn:
我一直想把这个方法写下来，因为它出奇地可重复，而且我希望有人能早点告诉我。在过去一年左右的时间里，相对于我2019年左右的基准，我的开发速度轻松提升了20倍，有时甚至更多。这不是因为我打字更快，也不是因为我偷工减料，而是因为我改变了使用AI的方式。

简单来说：我不在编辑器内使用AI。我在浏览器中并行使用两个AI，并保持完整的上下文。

具体设置如下：
我打开两个标签页：
一个AI充当“构建者”。它获得大量上下文并承担繁重的工作。
另一个AI充当审查者。它只查看差异并试图找出错误。

就这样。没有插件，没有特殊工具。只有浏览器标签页和终端。

关键部分是上下文。我不会只要求代码片段，而是粘贴整个文件或模块，并解释目标。在AI编写代码之前，我会要求它先解释方法，包括权衡。这迫使我保持对架构的控制，而不是盲目接受……

该帖子讨论了一位开发者因市场缺乏理想相机而自行打造相机的项目。核心话题围绕自制相机的技术挑战与当前相机市场的产品空白。

社区普遍赞赏项目的极客精神，多人表示期待看到相机实拍照片。有用户指出，奥林巴斯和松下已基本放弃M43系统的小型相机市场，并怀念类似GX85的便携机型；也有用户认为富士X-E5在参数上可与GX85媲美。讨论中提到关于相机兼容性的争议，例如松下镜头在奥林巴斯机身上是否受限的问题。在技术细节上，有用户针对手动攻丝的工具选择提出建议，认为亚马逊的廉价丝锥配合导向工具即可满足需求。

整体而言，社区认同小型化与画质兼顾的相机存在市场缺口，并对M43系统作为便携解决方案表示青睐，但具体机型选择及技术实现方式存在不同看法。

posts.title: Creating a bespoke data diode for air‑gapped networks
posts.author: nelop
posts.title_cn: 为隔离网络创建定制数据二极管
posts.abstract:
该帖子讨论了为物理隔离网络创建定制数据二极管的技术方案。核心话题是如何在保证单向数据传输的前提下，实现低成本、高安全性的跨网络通信。

讨论中出现了多种技术路线的争议。有人认为可直接采用光纤以太网方案，指出商用级方案已成熟且未来可升级至10Gbps；也有用户指出光纤方案需双向心跳信号，定制修改会推高成本。部分用户提出更简化的替代方案，如使用RS-232串口线物理切断发送针脚，或通过声电转换配合抗噪编码传输数据。

关于方案实用性存在分歧：有观点赞赏其创新性，但质疑图示方案的部署可靠性，认为更接近概念验证；另有用户强调硬件防火墙配合严格规则管理已能满足多数场景。讨论中形成的基本共识是，定制方案的核心优势在于通过点对点光隔离实现物理层面的防窃听，但实际带宽限制和工程化稳健性仍是主要挑战。

comments.author: bigfatkitten
comments.content: Why not use optical ethernet as ‘real’ cross domain solutions do? Probably cheaper if you don’t mind eBay, and gives you an easy upgrade path to 10Gbps or more in future.Two port NIC on the low side. Port 2 has its TX side connected to Port 1’s RX, just so the port will see a carrier and show link up. Port 1 TX goes to the high side machine’s RX, with TX left open.From here, you have a whole ton of protocol options.For things like syslog, you can just use a static ARP entry on the low side to forward events to the high side’s IP address via UDP.For reliable transport, there are lots of options for reliable multicast now using erasure coding etc that don’t require a reverse channel.
comments.content_cn: 为什么不采用真正跨域解决方案所使用的光以太网技术？如果不介意使用eBay平台，成本可能更低，且未来能轻松升级至10Gbps或更高速率。低安全区采用双端口网卡，端口2的发送端连接端口1的接收端，仅用于建立载波信号并显示链路连通。端口1的发送端连接高安全区设备的接收端，其发送端保持开放状态。由此可选用大量协议方案：对于系统日志传输，只需在低安全区设置静态ARP条目，即可通过UDP将事件转发至高安全区IP地址；对于可靠传输，现有多种基于擦除编码等技术的可靠组播方案，无需反向信道即可实现。

comments.author: mikewarot
comments.content: My understanding is that there has to be a heartbeat sent in both directions for fiber Ethernet to work. There are work arounds, but then you're back up into the commercial product price range.
comments.content_cn: 我的理解是，光纤以太网正常工作需要双向发送心跳信号。虽然存在一些变通方案，但那样成本又会回升到商用产品的价格区间。

comments.content: Just use DNS.
comments.content_cn: 直接使用DNS。

comments.content_cn: 本可以采用带有适当抗噪数字编码的扬声器和麦克风。

comments.content: I feel like it's easier to just have Ethernet and a strict HW firewall with the admin interfaces totally disabled (have to full reset to get back in).You can either just block packets in one direction, or you can add a small amount of risk and allow UDP and TCP with zero payload in one direction. That would allow you to reliably stream in one direction and request from either direction, albeit with a slightly exploitable channel (timing, reliability or the space of values allowed in the protocol).You already have to trust the RPI hardware to not enable WiFi on either side, so why not trust a router?
comments.content_cn: 我觉得更简单的做法是直接使用以太网并配置严格的硬件防火墙，同时完全禁用管理员界面（必须完全重置才能重新进入）。你可以选择单向阻断数据包，或者稍微增加一点风险，允许单向传输无负载的UDP和TCP数据。这样就能实现可靠的单向流传输，并允许双向请求，尽管会存在一个可能被利用的通道（涉及时序、可靠性或协议允许的数值范围）。既然你已经需要信任树莓派硬件不会在任意一端启用WiFi，那为何不信任路由器呢？

comments.content_cn: 正如我所描述的，在发送端使用双端口网卡可以解决这个问题。这正是像BAE系统这样的商业CDS供应商所采用的方法。

comments.content_cn: 我认为分立式光耦合器的优势在于保持通信的点对点特性，从而防止其他设备（无论是否恶意）进行“窃听”。低功率光信号无法穿透实体外壳；相比之下，要防止机械振动在耦合器之外泄露信息则困难得多——需要将扬声器和麦克风置于某种起低通滤波器作用的悬挂系统（如弹簧和减震器）上。

comments.content:

But I just wanted something simple for me, I know Linux and Raspberry pi's so decided to go down this route, having a pi on each side gives me the option to run scripts and tweak as required.
comments.content_cn: 是的，这个方法可行，解决这个问题有很多种方式，我听说过有人使用光纤连接并在一端进行处理。但我只想要一个简单的方案，我熟悉Linux和树莓派，所以决定采用这个方案，在两端各放一个树莓派让我可以根据需要运行脚本和进行调整。

comments.author: bmgxyz
comments.content: Shannon-Hartley says the theoretical maximum data rate for a channel with AWGN is proportional to bandwidth and the log of signal-to-noise ratio. For an off-the-shelf microphone/speaker pair, I think 16 kHz and 80 dB are probably decent guesses. That would give a theoretical maximum data rate of about 425 kb/s. The practical limit is probably much lower.It may be possible to increase the bandwidth by increasing the sample rate on both ends, but this quickly leaves the realm of consumer audio equipment (and consumer pricing). At some point you'd exceed the reasonable frequency responses for each device, as well as the medium. I imagine that air attenuates ultrasonic frequencies more than lower ones, but that's just a guess.
comments.content_cn:
香农-哈特利定理指出，加性高斯白噪声信道的理论最大数据传输速率与带宽和信噪比的对数成正比。对于市售的麦克风/扬声器组合，我认为16千赫兹带宽和80分贝信噪比可能是合理的估算值。这将得出约425千比特/秒的理论最大数据传输速率。实际限制很可能低得多。

通过提高两端的采样率或许可以增加带宽，但这很快就会超出消费级音频设备（及消费级价格）的范畴。在某些情况下，可能会超出每个设备以及传输介质的合理频率响应范围。我推测空气对超声波频率的衰减比对较低频率更显著，但这仅是猜测。

comments.author: XorNot
comments.content: All speakers can act as microphones. But due to physics you'd have a much harder time turning a photodiode into a light emitting one (the physics means you only can get IR out and the LED can't receive anything that way).
comments.content_cn: 所有扬声器都能充当麦克风使用。但由于物理原理的限制，将光电二极管转变为发光二极管会困难得多（物理特性决定了它只能发出红外线，且无法以这种方式接收任何信号）。

posts.title: Show HN: Tailsnitch – A security auditor for Tailscale
posts.author: thesubtlety
posts.title_cn: Show HN：Tailsnitch – Tailscale 安全审计工具
posts.abstract:
该讨论围绕Tailscale安全审计工具Tailsnitch展开，核心话题是探讨如何有效监控和审计Tailscale网络中的安全配置与用户活动。社区普遍认为该工具作为配置检查器很有价值，但也提出了更深入的需求。

有人认为工具应提供实时审计功能，例如在用户通过SSH连接管理员账户时发出通知，因为Tailscale后台服务本已掌握用户连接信息。也有用户指出，类似工具应原生集成到Tailscale平台中，建议增加“立即扫描”按钮或通过API提供定期审计报告，以提升企业级安全管理的便利性。讨论中提到，对于仍由资深开发者兼任运维的中型团队，建立完整的审计追踪至关重要，既能保障生产环境访问权限，又能满足合规要求。

部分用户关注工具的兼容性与检测范围，询问其是否支持Headscale开源方案，以及能否检测已知的安全漏洞。整体上，社区肯定该工具的创新性，并期待Tailscale官方进一步整合安全审计功能，同时通过开源协作完善相关特性。

comments.author: mikepurvis
comments.content: So this is a configuration linter; what I was hoping it might be is something that provides live auditd notices for when a tailscale user connects by SSH to a common "admin" account.The tailscale daemon definitely knows which user it is making the connection, as it publishes that info into the journal and I've seen people scrape it out of there, but I'd much rather it go through a structured reporting pipeline. AFAICT, tailscale itself provides several things that look like they're this, but aren't quite the right thing, for example https://tailscale.com/kb/1203/audit-logging is about logging changes to the tailnet itself (eg adding nodes), and https://tailscale.com/kb/1246/tailscale-ssh-session-recordin... is recording the ssh sessions rather than simple events for XYZ logged in / XYZ session idle / XYZ disconnected.(And yes, I know people have opinions about common admin accounts, but tailscale is another route into what FB described as far as everyone accessing the same root account but doing so with their own credentials [good!] rather than a shared key [very bad!]: https://engineering.fb.com/2016/09/12/security/scalable-and-...)
comments.content_cn: 所以这是一个配置检查工具；我原本希望它能提供实时审计通知，当Tailscale用户通过SSH连接到通用“管理员”账户时触发。Tailscale守护进程显然知道正在建立连接的用户身份，因为它会将此信息发布到系统日志中，我也见过有人从中提取数据，但我更希望这些信息能通过结构化的报告管道处理。据我所知，Tailscale本身提供了一些看似相关但并非完全符合需求的功能，例如https://tailscale.com/kb/1203/audit-logging 记录的是对Tailnet本身的更改（如添加节点），而https://tailscale.com/kb/1246/tailscale-ssh-session-recordin... 则是录制SSH会话，而非简单的“XYZ用户登录/会话闲置/断开连接”事件。（是的，我知道人们对通用管理员账户有不同看法，但Tailscale提供了另一种途径，类似于Facebook描述的方案——所有人访问同一个根账户，但使用各自的凭据[这很好！]而非共享密钥[这非常糟糕！]：https://engineering.fb.com/2016/09/12/security/scalable-and-...）

comments.content: (n=1, imho, ymmv, etc)No, not only should Tailscale offer a point in time report (click button in GUI, scan queued and report created, report link is preserved in GUI, any user with sufficient access can retrieve the report), they should expose whatever is needed via API to make these attestations available to automated GRC evidence collection systems (Vanta and Anecdotes, for example). Think continuous compliance monitoring of the software defined network tenant/control plane, similar to what you would get out of a CNAPP but scoped for this use case and more geared towards audit and compliance.I would be somewhat surprised if their enterprise users haven't or are not asking for this to be honest.
comments.content_cn: （个人观点，效果因人而异）不，Tailscale不仅应提供即时报告功能（在图形界面点击按钮，扫描队列并生成报告，报告链接保存在界面中，任何有足够权限的用户均可获取报告），还应通过API开放必要接口，使这些验证信息能够接入自动化GRC证据收集系统（例如Vanta和Anecdotes）。这相当于对软件定义网络的租户/控制平面进行持续合规监控，类似于CNAPP的功能，但更针对此使用场景，并更侧重于审计与合规。说实话，如果他们的企业用户尚未或没有提出此类需求，我反而会感到有些意外。

comments.author: thesubtlety
comments.content: Oh that's a cool idea. Super useful for detection and response teams, guessing they're able to get some of that by standard OS telemetry via agents/EDR.
comments.content_cn: 这个想法真棒。对于检测和响应团队来说超级有用，我猜他们能通过代理/终端检测与响应从标准操作系统的遥测数据中获取部分这类信息。

comments.author: mikepurvis
comments.content: Having an audit trail is really important for medium-sized shops where a lot of senior devs still have the keys to prod and kind of need to as they're still the defacto ops team and have to be able to get in quickly to investigate faults or poke at systems to get them back online.At the same time, when something is left in a bad state, you want to know how it got that way and when; not even necessarily just to punish people, but so that the right people are in the room to explain the full circumstances of what they did and why.
comments.content_cn: 对于中型团队而言，建立操作审计记录至关重要，因为许多资深开发人员仍掌握生产环境权限，且往往需要保留这种权限——他们实际上仍承担运维职责，必须能快速介入调查故障或调整系统以恢复服务。与此同时，当系统出现异常状态时，我们需要准确追溯问题发生的时间与成因；这不仅是为了追责，更是为了让相关责任人能够完整说明当时的操作背景与决策缘由。
